item.title: Day 67, Numbers 33-34
item.description: Chapter 33 recounts the journey of Israel by dividing it into segments. The Israelites left Egypt triumphantly in the sight of the Egyptians.

item.title: Day 67, Numbers 31-32
item.description: God orders Israel to take vengeance on Midian, for they caused Israel to sin at Peor. Balaam and the kings of Midian were killed.

item.title: Day 66, Numbers 28-30
item.description: God details laws concerning offerings at different times of the day and throughout the year. Each offering often includes some sort of animal, grain offering, drink offering, food offering, or sin offering.

item.title: Day 65, Numbers 26-27
item.description: God orders Moses to take a second census. Despite all the disasters God brought on Israel for their disobedience, remarkably, their total numbers were largely the same as the time of the first census.

item.title: Day 64, Numbers 23-25
item.description: Balaam gave a total of four oracles concerning Israel. Balaam went to look for omens from God for the first two, while for the final two, he was aware that God intended to bless Israel and did not go to look for omens from God.

item.title: Day 63, Numbers 21-22
item.description: The king of Arad is destroyed and his cities devoted to destruction. Afterwards, the people became impatient at their journey and grumbled against God and Moses.

item.title: Day 62, Numbers 18-20
item.description: God tells Aaron his duties and those of the Levites. The Levites are to keep guard and service the tent of meeting.

item.title: Day 61, Numbers 16-17
item.description: Korah, Dathan, Abiram, and 250 other chiefs of Israel rebel against Moses and Aaron. Korah was among those who guarded and serviced the holy things.

item.title: Day 60, Numbers 14-15, Psalm 90
item.description: On hearing the report of the spies, the people rebel and wish to return to Egypt. Moses, Aaron, Joshua, and Caleb were greatly grieved, for they believed that God would deliver the inhabitants of Canaan into their land.

item.title: Day 59, Numbers 11-13
item.description: After forming the covenant and leaving Sinai, the people begin complaining about their misfortunes. Fire comes down and consumes parts of the camp, and Moses prays on behalf of the people for the fire to stop.

item.title: Day 58, Numbers 8-10
item.description: God orders Moses to cleanse the Levites by sprinkling the water of purification and giving a grain and sin offering. The Levites are offered as a wave offering to God before the entire congregation.

item.title: Day 57, Numbers 7
item.description: Once the tabernacle and everything in it was consecrated, the chiefs of each tribe of Israel brought their offerings. The wagons and oxen were distributed to the sons of Gershon and Merari.

item.title: Day 56, Numbers 5-6
item.description: A person who is unclean is to be put outside the camp because God, who is holy, dwells within the camp.

item.title: Day 55, Numbers 3-4
item.description: A count of the sons of Aaron and the Levites is performed. At the same time, the duties of the Levites are given.

item.title: Day 54, Numbers 1-2
item.description: God tells Moses to take a census of Israel. All those who are of fighting age are to be counted. The smallest tribe is Manasseh and the largest is Judah.

item.title: Day 53, Leviticus 26-27
item.description: God tells Israel the blessings he will give them if they obey him. If Israel obeys God, they will have plentiful harvests and peace, overwhelming victory over their enemies, and their land will be free from wild beasts.

item.title: Day 52, Leviticus 24-25
item.description: Commands regarding the arrangements for the lamp and bread of the tabernacle are given. The punishment for blasphemy is death, though this law is different in that it calls for the entire congregation of Israel to stone the blasphemer.

item.title: Day 51, Leviticus 22-23
item.description: God gives instructions regarding what is to happen should Aaron or his sons become unclean. If that is to happen, that person is cut off from God for a day.

item.title: Day 50, Leviticus 19-21
item.description: God begins the next section of laws by declaring his holiness and how he is the God of Israel. Because he is holy, the people are also to be holy in the way they live.

item.title: Day 49, Leviticus 16-18
item.description: God gives laws for the Day of Atonement, a day which Aaron is to make atonement for the entirety of Israel.

item.title: Day 48, Leviticus 14-15
item.description: God gives laws regarding bodily discharges and the cleansing of lepers and houses. Throughout the entire passage, God makes it very clear that there is a tight relationship between one’s physical state and spiritual state.

item.title: Day 47, Leviticus 11-13
item.description: God gives instructions regarding what the Israelites can and cannot eat. Among the clean animals are those with a split hoof, cloven-footed, and chew the cud.

item.title: Day 46, Leviticus 8-10
item.description: Aaron and his sons are consecrated as priests according to the previous instructions given by God in Exodus. They are washed and clothed with the priest’s garments.

item.title: Day 45, Leviticus 5-7
item.description: God also takes into account one’s ability to give the sin offering when he gives the laws. Among the offences that require a sin offering include uncleanness, failure to testify, or any sort of rash oath.

item.title: Day 44, Leviticus 1-4
item.description: The laws concerning burnt offerings, peace offerings, and sin offerings all use some sort of animal as the offering. All sacrifices and offerings take place just outside the tent of meeting.

item.title: Day 43, Exodus 39-40
item.description: The Israelites made the priestly garments as God commanded Moses. They made the ephod, the engraved onyx stones, the breastpiece with its four rows of jewels, the blue robe of the ephod, the bells and pomegranates, coats, turban, sash, and the inscribed plate of the crown.

item.title: Day 42, Exodus 36-38
item.description: The Israelites give their contributions for the tabernacle out of their own free will. They gave so much that they had more than needed.

item.title: Day 41, Exodus 33-35
item.description: Moses and the people are ordered to head to the Promised land. However, God will no longer go among the Israelites even though he will still drive out the people there.

item.title: Day 40, Exodus 30-32
item.description: Laws for the altar of incense are given. Only Aaron is able to burn incense on it. No unauthorized incense or offerings are allowed on the altar.

item.title: Day 39, Exodus 28-29
item.description: Instructions for the priests' garments are given. These garments are to be worn by Aaron and his sons. Aaron’s garments are to be made of gold, linen, and various yarns.

item.title: Day 38, Exodus 25-27
item.description: God gives instructions for the sanctuary so that he can dwell among the people. The materials to be collected are to be given by those whose hearts have been moved.

item.title: Day 37. Exodus 22-24
item.description: Laws regarding repayment of damages are given. These laws show that God ensures that those who are wronged are repaid, and those who do wrong pay the full amount.

item.title: Day 36, Exodus 19-21
item.description: The Israelites arrive at Mount Sinai. There, God begins to establish the Mosaic covenant. As the offspring of Abraham, Israel inherits the Abrahamic covenant as a people and get a new covenant, one that would set apart Israel as God’s treasured possession.

item.title: Day 35, Exodus 16-18
item.description: As Israel travelled, they complained against Moses and Aaron, for they did not have any food. Moses brought their complaint to God, and God promised to send food.

item.title: Day 34, Exodus 13-15
item.description: The Feast of Unleavened bread was established so that the people of Israel may remember their deliverance from their Egyptian oppressors, for they left in haste.

item.title: Day 33, Exodus 10-12
item.description: During the plague of locusts, Pharaoh’s servants urge Pharaoh to let the people of Israel go. At this point, the economy of Egypt was ruined.

item.title: Day 32, Exodus 7-9
item.description: In effect, Moses is God’s ambassador, as his words are the words of God. God reveals to Moses what is about to happen to Egypt, and charges them to go to Pharaoh again.

item.title: Day 31, Exodus 4-6
item.description: Moses continues to voice his fears and complaints. God addresses his first by giving him three signs to perform so that Israel may believe.

item.title: Day 30, Exodus 1-3
item.description: The children of Israel increased in number and strength. In time, the Egyptians began to fear the Israelites and oppressed them, making them slaves.

item.title: Day 29, Genesis 48-50
item.description: The progression of the final story is different, as one would expect for God to appear to the next inheritor of the Abrahamic covenant.

item.title: Day 28, Genesis 46-47
item.description: Jacob and his family begins the journey to Egypt. God promises that he will go down with them to Egypt, and by his hand, he will bring Jacob back up.

item.title: Day 27, Genesis 43-45
item.description: The food that the brothers got from Egypt has now run out, and Jacob tells them to go back to Egypt to get more food.

item.title: Day 26, Genesis 41-42
item.description: During Joseph’s imprisonment, Pharaoh had two dreams. However, no one in Egypt was able to tell Pharaoh what it meant. It was at this time that the cup bearer remembered how Joseph interpreted their dreams for them and told Pharaoh about Joseph.

item.title: Day 25, Genesis 38-40
item.description: Judah became the father of three sons. The first son married Tamar, but he died shortly after without a heir. His second son was to raise offspring with Tamar on behalf of the first, but he didn’t want to have his brother’s offspring.

item.title: Day 24, Genesis 35-37
item.description: God has now fulfilled his end of the deal with Jacob. He has safely brought Jacob back to the land of Canaan and protected him from his brother and given him prosperity.

item.title: Day 23, Genesis 32-34
item.description: Throughout this passage, we see further evidence of God using events and people to separate for himself a nation distinct that will inherit the Abrahamic covenant.

item.title: Day 22, Genesis 30-31
item.description: From Bilhah on behalf of Rachel, Dan and Naphtali were born. From Zilpah on behalf of Lea, Gad and Asher were born.

item.title: Day 21, Genesis 27-29
item.description: As the firstborn, Esau is called in to Isaac so that he may eat of the game Esau hunts and bless him.

item.title: Day 20, Genesis 25-26
item.description: Abraham had many other sons after Isaac, but the inheritance went only to Isaac. Before Jacob and Esau are born to Isaac, God tells Isaac and Rebekah that the two children are two nations, but the older will serve the younger.

item.title: Day 19, Genesis 22-24
item.description: When God tests Abraham, Abraham readily obeys, willing to give up the manifestation of God’s promise in obedience to God. Curiously, Abraham tells his son Isaac that God will provide the lamb, although God has not said anything regarding that.

item.title: Day 18, Genesis 19-21
item.description: When the two angels arrive at Sodom, Lot greets and invites them to spend the night at his house. However, the men of the city, in their wickedness, ask the two men for sex.

item.title: Day 17, Genesis 16-18
item.description: Sarai, unable to bear children, gives her servant Hagar to Abram. Abram consents, even though the covenant with God was made shortly prior to this.

item.title: Day 16, Genesis 12-15
item.description: God tells Abram to leave the land he is living in and go to a land that God will show him.

item.title: Day 15, Job 40-42
item.description: In the face of God’s majesty and revelation, Job finds no answer to God. God continues in his challenge to Job.

item.title: Day 14, Job 38-39
item.description: God responds to Job’s complaints in a speech placing emphasis on his sovereignty and power. Although Job may not remember or perceive his presence, God is there, moving the things in the world in accordance to his will.

item.title: Day 13, Job 35-37
item.description: Elihu opens his condemnation of Job much differently than his friends. Whereas the others launched accusations, Elihu acknowledges the suffering that Job is going through.

item.title: Day 12, Job 32-34
item.description: Elihu finally decides to speak up. He is angry at Job’s friends for failing to find an answer to Job and is angry at Job for justifying himself rather than God.

item.title: Day 11, Job 29-31
item.description: Job summarizes his defence in three sections. Job wishes for the old days when God blessed him. He was respected by others and honour was shown to him.

item.title: Day 10, Job 24-28
item.description: Job describes the suffering of the poor. Although they do much work, their work is in vain. There are cries and pleas for help, but there is no charge from God.

item.title: Day 9, Job 21-23
item.description: While Job’s friends continue to insist that the wicked are brought to ruin, Job counters by describing the prosperity of the wicked.

item.title: Day 8, Job 17-20
item.description: Job continues elaborating that apart from God, there is no hope. Although upright people see his suffering, none have lifted a finger to help him.

item.title: Day 7, Job 14-16
item.description: Job proceeds to talk about the pointlessness of life, since all men will eventually die. If that is so, then it makes sense for Job to want to bring his case before God.

item.title: Day 6, Job 10-13
item.description: Job continues with a plea to God, asking why God had brought so much suffering into his life. Zopher mocks Job in response, saying that Job is already getting repaid much less than his guilt deserves.

item.title: Day 5, Job 6-9
item.description: Job responds to Eliphaz’s answer. He maintains that his complaints are just and acknowledges once again the sovereignty of God. He maintains that he is still in obedience to God, as he finds the misfortunes that have come upon him to be in God’s will.

item.title: Day 4, Job 1-5
item.description: Job was one of the greatest men in the east. He was blameless and righteous before before God and feared God.

item.title: Day 3, Genesis 8-11
item.description: God remembered Noah and those that he had spared from the flood. Therefore, God caused the floodwaters to recede. When land could be seen, Noah sent out a raven and a dove several times, continually checking for the day which the floodwaters completely recede.

item.title: Day 2, Genesis 4-7
item.description: Adam and Eve had two sons, Cain and Abel. Both of them brought an offering to God, but God was only pleased with Abel’s offering of his flock’s firstborn and fat portions.

item.title: Day 1, Genesis 1-3
item.description: The world before creation is described as formless, empty, and dark. Yet, the presence of God is there, it is clear that wherever God is, something is bound to happen.
